member.name: T:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle
member.summary: Represents a unit independent angle using a single-precision floating-point internal representation.

member.name: F:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Degree
member.summary: A value that specifies the size of a single degree.

member.name: F:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Minute
member.summary: A value that specifies the size of a single minute.

member.name: F:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Second
member.summary: A value that specifies the size of a single second.

member.name: F:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Radian
member.summary: A value that specifies the size of a single radian.

member.name: F:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Milliradian
member.summary: A value that specifies the size of a single milliradian.

member.name: F:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Gradian
member.summary: A value that specifies the size of a single gradian.

member.name: F:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.radians_
member.summary: The internal representation of the angle.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.#ctor(System.Single,HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleType)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the SharpDX.AngleSingle structure with the given unit dependant angle and unit type.
member.param: A unit dependant measure of the angle.
The type of unit the angle argument is.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the SharpDX.AngleSingle structure using the arc length formula (θ = s/r).

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Wrap
member.summary: Wraps this SharpDX.AngleSingle to be in the range [π, -π].

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.WrapPositive
member.summary: Wraps this SharpDX.AngleSingle to be in the range [0, 2π).

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Revolutions
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of revolutions this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents.

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Degrees
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of degrees this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents.

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Minutes
member.summary: Gets or sets the minutes component of the degrees this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents. When setting the minutes, if the value is in the range (-60, 60) the whole degrees are not changed; otherwise, the whole degrees may be changed. Fractional values may set the seconds component.

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Seconds
member.summary: Gets or sets the seconds of the degrees this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents. When setting the seconds, if the value is in the range (-60, 60) the whole minutes or whole degrees are not changed; otherwise, the whole minutes or whole degrees may be changed.

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Radians
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of radians this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents.

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Milliradians
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of milliradians this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents. One milliradian is equal to 1/(2000π).

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Gradians
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of gradians this SharpDX.AngleSingle represents.

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.IsRight
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is a right angle (i.e. 90° or π/2).

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.IsStraight
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is a straight angle (i.e. 180° or π).

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.IsFullRotation
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is a full rotation angle (i.e. 360° or 2π).

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.IsOblique
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is an oblique angle (i.e. is not 90° or a multiple of 90°).

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.IsAcute
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is an acute angle (i.e. less than 90° but greater than 0°).

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.IsObtuse
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is an obtuse angle (i.e. greater than 90° but less than 180°).

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.IsReflex
member.summary: Gets a System.Boolean that determines whether this SharpDX.Angle is a reflex angle (i.e. greater than 180° but less than 360°).

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Complement
member.summary: Gets a SharpDX.AngleSingle instance that complements this angle (i.e. the two angles add to 90°).

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Supplement
member.summary: Gets a SharpDX.AngleSingle instance that supplements this angle (i.e. the two angles add to 180°).

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.Wrap(HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle)

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle.WrapPositive(HelixToolkit.Maths.AngleSingle)
member.summary: Wraps the SharpDX.AngleSingle given in the value argument to be in the range [0, 2π).

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.BoundingFrustum.GetZoomToExtentsShiftDistance(System.Numerics.Vector3[])
member.summary: Get the distance which when added to camera position along the lookat direction will do the effect of zoom to extents (zoom to fit) operation, so all the passed points will fit in the current view. if the returned value is positive, the camera will move toward the lookat direction (ZoomIn). if the returned value is negative, the camera will move in the reverse direction of the lookat direction (ZoomOut).

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Collision.RayIntersectsPoint(HelixToolkit.Maths.Ray@,System.Numerics.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a point.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Collision.RayIntersectsRay(HelixToolkit.Maths.Ray@,HelixToolkit.Maths.Ray@,System.Numerics.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the point of intersection, or if there was no intersection.
member.remarks: This method performs a ray vs ray intersection test based on the following formula from Goldman. s = det([o_2 - o_1, d_2, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 t = det([o_2 - o_1, d_1, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 Where o_1 is the position of the first ray, o_2 is the position of the second ray, d_1 is the normalized direction of the first ray, d_2 is the normalized direction of the second ray, det denotes the determinant of a matrix, x denotes the cross product, [ ] denotes a matrix, and || || denotes the length or magnitude of a vector.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Collision.RayIntersectsPlane(HelixToolkit.Maths.Ray@,System.Numerics.Plane@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection, or 0 if there was no intersection.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Collision.RayIntersectsPlane(HelixToolkit.Maths.Ray@,System.Numerics.Plane@,System.Numerics.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the point of intersection, or if there was no intersection.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Collision.RayIntersectsTriangle(HelixToolkit.Maths.Ray@,System.Numerics.Vector3@,System.Numerics.Vector3@,System.Numerics.Vector3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a triangle.
member.param: The first vertex of the triangle to test.
The second vertex of the triangle to test.
The third vertex of the triangle to test.
When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection, or 0 if there was no intersection.
member.remarks: This method tests if the ray intersects either the front or back of the triangle. If the ray is parallel to the triangle's plane, no intersection is assumed to have happened. If the intersection of the ray and the triangle is behind the origin of the ray, no intersection is assumed to have happened. In both cases of assumptions, this method returns false.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Collision.RayIntersectsTriangle(HelixToolkit.Maths.Ray@,System.Numerics.Vector3@,System.Numerics.Vector3@,System.Numerics.Vector3@,System.Numerics.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a triangle.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Color3.#ctor(System.Single[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct.
member.param: The values to assign to the red, green, and blue components of the color. This must be an array with three elements.
member.exception: Thrown when is null.
Thrown when contains more or less than four elements.

member.name: P:HelixToolkit.Maths.Color3.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets or sets the component at the specified index.
member.value: The value of the red, green, or blue component, depending on the index.
member.param: The index of the component to access. Use 0 for the red component, 1 for the green component, and 2 for the blue component.
member.returns: The value of the component at the specified index.
member.exception: Thrown when the is out of the range [0, 2].

member.returns: A packed integer containing all three color components. The alpha channel is set to 255.

member.summary: Converts the color into a packed integer.
member.returns: A packed integer containing all three color components. The alpha channel is set to 255.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.MatrixHelper.Orthogonalize(System.Numerics.Matrix4x4@)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.MatrixHelper.Orthonormalize(System.Numerics.Matrix4x4@)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified matrix.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized matrix of the decomposition.
When the method completes, contains the right triangular matrix of the decomposition.

member.summary: Decomposes a matrix into a lower triangular matrix L and an orthonormalized matrix Q.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the lower triangular matrix of the decomposition.
When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized matrix of the decomposition.

member.summary: Decomposes a uniform scale matrix into a scale, rotation, and translation. A uniform scale matrix has the same scale in every axis.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the scaling component of the decomposed matrix.
When the method completes, contains the rotation component of the decomposed matrix.
When the method completes, contains the translation component of the decomposed matrix.
member.remarks: This method is designed to decompose only an SRT transformation matrix that has the same scale in every axis.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.MatrixHelper.UpperTriangularForm(System.Numerics.Matrix4x4@,System.Numerics.Matrix4x4@)
member.summary: Brings the matrix into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The matrix to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular matrix.
member.remarks: If the matrix is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the matrix represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.MatrixHelper.ReducedRowEchelonForm(System.Numerics.Matrix4x4@,System.Numerics.Vector4@,System.Numerics.Matrix4x4@,System.Numerics.Vector4@)
member.summary: Brings the matrix into reduced row echelon form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The matrix to put into reduced row echelon form.
The fifth column of the matrix.
When the method completes, contains the resultant matrix after the operation.
When the method completes, contains the resultant fifth column of the matrix.

remarks.para: The fifth column is often called the augmented part of the matrix. This is because the fifth column is really just an extension of the matrix so that there is a place to put all of the non-zero components after the operation is complete.
Often times the resultant matrix will the identity matrix or a matrix similar to the identity matrix. Sometimes, however, that is not possible and numbers other than zero and one may appear.

This method can be used to solve systems of linear equations. Upon completion of this method, the will contain the solution for the system. It is up to the user to analyze both the input and the result to determine if a solution really exists.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Matrix3x3.Determinant
member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the Matrix3x3.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Matrix3x3.Transpose
member.summary: Transposes the Matrix3x3.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Matrix3x3.Decompose(System.Numerics.Vector3@,System.Numerics.Quaternion@)
member.summary: Decomposes a Matrix3x3 into a scale, rotation, and translation.

When the method completes, contains the rotation component of the decomposed Matrix3x3.
member.remarks: This method is designed to decompose an SRT transformation Matrix3x3 only.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Matrix3x3.DecomposeUniformScale(System.Single@,System.Numerics.Quaternion@)
member.summary: Decomposes a uniform scale matrix into a scale, rotation, and translation. A uniform scale matrix has the same scale in every axis.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the scaling component of the decomposed matrix.
When the method completes, contains the rotation component of the decomposed matrix.
member.remarks: This method is designed to decompose only an SRT transformation matrix that has the same scale in every axis.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize(HelixToolkit.Maths.Matrix3x3@,HelixToolkit.Maths.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthogonalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Matrix3x3.UpperTriangularForm(HelixToolkit.Maths.Matrix3x3@,HelixToolkit.Maths.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Brings the Matrix3x3 into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The Matrix3x3 to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular Matrix3x3.
member.remarks: If the Matrix3x3 is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the Matrix3x3 represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Vector2Helper.Orthogonalize(System.Numerics.Vector2[],System.Numerics.Vector2[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Vector2Helper.Orthonormalize(System.Numerics.Vector2[],System.Numerics.Vector2[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Vector2Helper.TransformCoordinate(System.Numerics.Vector2@,System.Numerics.Matrix4x4@,System.Numerics.Vector2@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Vector2Helper.TransformCoordinate(System.Numerics.Vector2,System.Numerics.Matrix4x4)

This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation on an array of vectors using the given .

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Vector2Helper.TransformNormal(System.Numerics.Vector2@,System.Numerics.Matrix4x4@,System.Numerics.Vector2@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Vector3Helper.Orthogonalize(System.Numerics.Vector3[],System.Numerics.Vector3[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Vector3Helper.Orthonormalize(System.Numerics.Vector3[],System.Numerics.Vector3[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Vector3Helper.TransformCoordinate(System.Numerics.Vector3@,System.Numerics.Matrix4x4@,System.Numerics.Vector3@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:HelixToolkit.Maths.Vector3Helper.TransformNormal(System.Numerics.Vector3@,System.Numerics.Matrix4x4@,System.Numerics.Vector3@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

The diagnostic ID is shown in build output for warnings and errors.
This property represents the unique ID that can be used to suppress the warnings or errors, if needed.

member.remarks: An example format string is https://contoso.com/obsoletion-warnings/{0}.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnscopedRefAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate a byref escapes and is not scoped.

remarks.para: There are several cases where the C# compiler treats a as implicitly - where the compiler does not allow the to escape the method.

For example:
for instance methods.
parameters that refer to types.
parameters.
This attribute is used in those instances where the should be allowed to escape.

Applying this attribute, in any form, has impact on consumers of the applicable API. It is necessary for API authors to understand the lifetime implications of applying this attribute and how it may impact their users.

member.name: T:System.Index
member.summary: Represent a type can be used to index a collection either from the start or the end.

member.name: M:System.Index.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Construct an Index using a value and indicating if the index is from the start or from the end.
member.param: The index value. it has to be zero or positive number.
Indicating if the index is from the start or from the end.
member.remarks: If the Index constructed from the end, index value 1 means pointing at the last element and index value 0 means pointing at beyond last element.

member.name: P:System.Index.Start
member.summary: Create an Index pointing at first element.

member.name: P:System.Index.End
member.summary: Create an Index pointing at beyond last element.

member.name: M:System.Index.FromStart(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create an Index from the start at the position indicated by the value.
member.param: The index value from the start.

member.name: M:System.Index.FromEnd(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create an Index from the end at the position indicated by the value.
member.param: The index value from the end.

member.name: P:System.Index.Value
member.summary: Returns the index value.

member.name: P:System.Index.IsFromEnd
member.summary: Indicates whether the index is from the start or the end.

member.name: M:System.Index.GetOffset(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate the offset from the start using the giving collection length.
member.param: The length of the collection that the Index will be used with. length has to be a positive value
member.remarks: For performance reason, we don't validate the input length parameter and the returned offset value against negative values. we don't validate either the returned offset is greater than the input length. It is expected Index will be used with collections which always have non negative length/count. If the returned offset is negative and then used to index a collection will get out of range exception which will be same affect as the validation.

member.param: An object to compare with this object

member.name: M:System.Range.GetOffsetAndLength(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate the start offset and length of range object using a collection length.
member.param: The length of the collection that the range will be used with. length has to be a positive value.
member.remarks: For performance reason, we don't validate the input length parameter against negative values. It is expected Range will be used with collections which always have non negative length/count. We validate the range is inside the length scope though.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsExternalInit

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ModuleInitializerAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate to the compiler that a method should be called in its containing module's initializer.
member.remarks:
When one or more valid methods with this attribute are found in a compilation, the compiler will emit a module initializer which calls each of the attributed methods.
Certain requirements are imposed on any method targeted with this attribute: - The method must be `static`. - The method must be an ordinary member method, as opposed to a property accessor, constructor, local function, etc. - The method must be parameterless. - The method must return `void`. - The method must not be generic or be contained in a generic type. - The method's effective accessibility must be `internal` or `public`.
The specification for module initializers in the .NET runtime can be found here: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/specs/Ecma-335-Augments.md#module-initializer

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.OverloadResolutionPriorityAttribute
